attributes.title: Der Zusammenhang von Technologienutzung und analoger Freiwilligenarbeit

q1.value: Der Zusammenhang von Technologienutzung und analoger Freiwilligenarbeit

q3.value: This research contributes to the understanding of the relationship between technology usage and the motivations of volunteering. As part of a cooperative project, I will investigate whether altruistic and self-serving motives of volunteering correlate with certain types of technology usage such as smartphone usage, social media usage, and internet searching.

q4.value:
•	1: Volunteering correlates positively with technology usage.
•	2: Altruistic and self-serving motives of volunteering correlate positively with internet searching.
•	3: Self-serving motives of volunteering correlate positively with social media usage.
•	4: Altruistic motives of volunteering correlate negatively with social media usage.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a cross-sectional survey. Survey measures are social bonds, self-awareness, social responsibility, self-esteem / recognition, social influence, occupational balance, career, political responsibility, personal experience, smartphone usage, general social media usage, internet searching, and video gaming. These scales will be presented in a random order.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: No data has been collected yet.

question.value: Participants will be recruited among members of the “Dortmunder Jugendring”, university students at a large university in Western Germany and via social platforms. Psychology students will earn course credit. We will create a cross-sectional online study using Qualtrics. With respect to eligibility participants must be at least 18 years old. Those who are assigned to the test group must have been volunteering at least once per month for at least since six months. Those who are volunteering less are assigned to the control group.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 168 participants.

q14.value:
•	Sample size computation: For correlation analyses based upon .8 statistical power, with error probability of .05, and an estimated medium effect size of .5. Using the G*power program, the required sample size is N = 64 (two-tailed test).
•	As the study is part of a larger cooperative study, the actual minimum sample size is N = 84 (two-tailed test).

q15.value: Data collection will be finished on 12. April 2020.

question.value:
•	The Skalen zur Einstellungsstruktur ehrenamtlicher Helfer (SEEH) (Bierhoff, Schülken, & Hoof, 2007) is used to asses the relevant motives of volunteering. It is measured with 26 items on nine-point Likert scales.
•	Four selected subscales of the Media and Technology Usage and Attitudes Scale (MTUAS)  (Rosen, Whaling, Carrier, Cheever, & Rokkum, 2013)  are used to asses the technology usage. It is measured with 25 items on ten-point Likert scales.
•	Covariates: Sex, age, occupation, and length of volunteering.
Hypotheses 1 to 4 will be tested by correlation analyses (Pearson correlation, two-tailed).

q22.value: Only participants who meet the criteria for participation in the study will be included in the data analysis (see data collection procedures). For example, we will exclude people who are under 18.

q23.value: Only people who have answered all items from at least one scale are included.

attributes.title: Perceived Psychological Safety and Causal Attributions of Errors of Working Students: The Mediating Role of Error Orientation

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Perceived Psychological Safety and Causal Attributions of Errors of Working Students: The Mediating Role of Error Orientation

sample.value: With regards to the number of items in our questionnaire and the planned statistical analyses, the sample size is going to consist of at least 200 participants. The calculation of the sample size is based on a rule of having at least five participants per item in the questionnaire.

analyses.value: We will test whether the assumptions of a logistic regression are met before we conduct a mediation analysis with perceived psychological safety as the IV, the three error orientations as three separate mediators, and functional causal attributions of errors as a dichotomous DV. The analyses will be performed with the PROCESS macro in SPSS.

dependent.value:
Causal attributions of errors: The participants will be asked to think about an error they committed at work and to keep it in mind while answering the items. Their attribution of the error will be assessed with the Causal Dimension Scale II (McAuley, Duncan, & Russell, 1992).

Locus of causality: sum of the items 1, 6, and 9
- Internal: scores between 14 and 24
- External: scores between 3 and 13

Stability: sum of the items 3, 7, and 11
- Stable: scores between 14 and 24
- Unstable: scores between 3 and 13

Based on their scores on locus of causality and stability, participants will be assigned to either of the two categories functional vs. dysfunctional causal attributions of errors according to the following scheme:

Functional (internal-unstable)
Locus of causality: 14-24
Stability: 3-13

Dysfunctional (internal-stable)
Locus of causality: 14-24
Stability: 14-24

Dysfunctional (external-unstable)
Locus of causality: 3-13
Stability: 3-13

Dysfunctional (external-stable)
Locus of causality: 3-13
Stability: 14-24

Additionally, demographic variables will be collected: age, gender, organizational tenure, years of work experience, educational background, and field of studies. Out of these variables, age, gender and organizational tenure will be included as covariates.

conditions.value: Based on their native language, participants will be assigned to either a Swedish or a German version of the questionnaire.

hypothesis.value:
Main question: Does error orientation mediate the relationship between perceived psychological safety and causal attributions of errors in working students?

Hypothesis 1: Perceived psychological safety is positively related to (a) learning from errors orientation and negatively related to (b) orientation toward covering errors and to (c) avoidant error orientation in working students.

Hypothesis 2a: The higher the learning from errors orientation in working students, the higher the probability of them making functional causal attributions of errors.

Hypothesis 2b: The higher the avoidant error orientation in working students, the lower the probability of them making functional causal attributions of errors.

Hypothesis 2c: The higher the orientation toward covering errors in working students, the lower the probability of them making functional causal attributions of errors.

Hypothesis 3a: Learning from errors orientation mediates the relationship between perceived psychological safety and the probability of functional causal attributions of errors in working students.

Hypothesis 3b: Avoidant error orientation mediates the relationship between perceived psychological safety and the probability of functional causal attributions of errors in working students.

Hypothesis 3c: An orientation toward covering errors mediates the relationship between perceived psychological safety and the probability of functional causal attributions of errors in working students.

Based on previous research, the variables age, gender and organizational tenure are expected to influence the relationship between perceived psychological safety and the probability of functional causal attributions of errors. Therefore, these variables will be included as covariates.

study_type_other.value: Survey study as part of a master thesis

attributes.title: Comparative effectiveness and safety of integrase inhibitor-, rilpivirine- and efavirenz-based triple-drug regimens as initial treatment for HIV-1 infected adults: a protocol for Bayesian analysis

q1.value: Comparative effectiveness and safety of integrase inhibitor-, rilpivirine- and efavirenz-based triple-drug regimens as initial treatment for HIV-1 infected adults: a protocol for a Bayesian analysis

q2.value: Ke Zhang, Yang Zhang, Aixin Li, Meixia Gao, Shui Jiang, Chunxiang Guo, Tong Zhang, Hao Wu, Xiaojie Huang, Guanzhi Chen

q3.value:
According to current guideline [1], antiretroviral therapy (ART) should be used as soon as possible after the diagnosis of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. The initial ART recommended [1] for HIV type 1 (HIV-1) infected adults consists of two nucleoside reverse-transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and a third agent. The third agent can be a protease inhibitor (PI), a non-nucleoside reverse-transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) or an integrase inhibitor (INSTI). 
    The following four drugs are integrase inhibitors: raltegravir (RAL), elvitegravir (EVG), dolutegravir (DTG), bictegravir (BIC). NNRTIs of our interest are efavirenz (EFV) and rilpivirine (RPV). And some of NRTIs commonly used in recent years are tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (TDF), emtricitabine (FTC), lamivudine (3TC), tenofovir alafenamide (TAF), abacavir (ABC) and etc.
    We will compare the efficacy and safety of some 3-drug regimens as initial treatment for HIV-1 infected adults.

q4.value: We want to demonstrate if integrase inhibitor-based triple-drug regimens are superior to rilpivirine- or efavirenz-based triple-drug regimens in both efficacy and safety.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Our analysis is a network meta-analysis.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
We searched PubMed/MEDLINE, Embase, Web of Science and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials on January 8, 2020. We also searched the clinical trial registry (ClinicalTrials.gov) and references of published systematic reviews and meta-analyses for eligible study. The appendix provides the terms and full search strategy used in PubMed.
Inclusion criteria:
(1) Phase 3 or 4 randomized controlled trials of 48 or 96 weeks' duration 
(2) Treatment-naive adults with HIV-1 infection 
(3) ART regimens with three antiretroviral drugs which included 2 NRTIs (backbones) plus one core agent from INSTIs or NNRTIs (The backbones of our interest were TDF+FTC/3TC, TAF+FTC and ABC+3TC. Core drugs of our interest were RAL, EVG, DTG, BIC, EFV and RPV. Pharmacokinetic enhancer in treatment regimens was not involved in counting.) 
(4) All drugs were standard-dose and low-dose EFV (400mg) was also be included. 
(5) The study compared at least any two regimens of our interest and reported at least one of outcomes of our interest. 
Exclusion criteria:
(1) Articles that didn’t specify in a regimen which three drugs used
(2) Articles were not in English.
(3) Studies in which the entire population was HIV-infected with tuberculosis 

Two investigators (Ke Zhang and Chunxiang Guo) screened titles and abstracts of studies independently. Two independent investigators (Ke Zhang and Aixin Li) will do full-text review and data extraction. Throughout the process, if a disagreement arises between two researchers doing the same work, they resolve it through discussion or seek help from a new researcher (Yang Zhang).

q13.value: It depends on how many participants are in studies that meet the inclusion criteria.

question.value:
We will analyze outcomes separately according to two timepoints: 48 weeks and 96 weeks.
The primary efficacy outcome is the proportion of patients with virologic suppression (With reference to FDA guidance [2], in order of preference, the following outcomes can be viewed as VS: FDA Snapshot-50, time to loss of virologic response-50, confirmed virologic response-50, and HIV RNA less than 50 copies/ml). The secondary outcome of efficacy is the change in cluster of differentiation 4 positive (CD4+) T-cells count from baseline.
Safety outcomes (secondary outcomes) are deaths, deaths related to study drugs, discontinuations, adverse events, adverse events due to study drugs and serious adverse events.

The quality of each trial selected for inclusion in this analysis will be assessed using the Cochrane Risk of Bias instrument. Additionally, we will refer to the method proposed by professor Salanti et al and employ Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation (GRADE) system for rating overall quality of evidence [3].
We will break the analysis into two steps. First, we will conduct pairwise meta-analyses and identify the level of heterogeneity using the I² statistic [4]. We consider that study leading to high heterogeneity (I² <50%) is not suitable for inclusion in our analysis. Second, we will conduct network meta-analyses using Bayesian hierarchical models. Markov chain Monte Carlo methods will be used in the analysis. A burn-in of 20,000 simulations will be discarded, followed by 100,000 simulations on 4 chains to estimate the sampled parameters. Potential scale reduction factor <1.2 is acceptable and if it does not reach the corresponding value, add another 10,000 iterations. We will choose the fixed effects model unless the deviance information criterion (DIC) value of the random effects model is more than 3 less than that of the fixed effects model. Consistency will be identified by node-splitting analysis and comparing DIC values of consistency model and inconsistency model. We’ll choose corresponding models for binomial outcomes and continuous outcomes. Results will be presented as odds ratios or mean differences with corresponding 95% credible intervals. We will use R software for calculations and drawing graphs.

q22.value:
Exclusion criteria:
(1) Articles that didn’t specify in a regimen which three drugs used
(2) Articles were not in English.
(3) Studies in which the entire population was HIV-infected with tuberculosis

q24.value: Analysis of viral suppression in two subgroups of subjects with baseline viral load ≤100,000 and >100,000 RNA copies/mL

q25.value:
1 Panel on Antiretroviral Guidelines for Adults and Adolescents. Guidelines for the Use of Antiretroviral Agents in Adults and Adolescents with HIV. Department of Health and Human Services. Available at http://www.aidsinfo.nih.gov/ContentFiles/AdultandAdolescentGL.pdf. Accessed [February 2020]
2 U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Guidance for Industry: Human Immunodeficiency Virus-1 Infection: Developing Antiretroviral Drugs for Treatment. 2013, http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/GuidanceComplianceRegulatoryInformation/Guidances/UCM355128.pdf. Accessed [February 2020]
3 Salanti G, Del Giovane C, Chaimani A, Caldwell DM, Higgins JP. Evaluating the quality of evidence from a network meta-analysis. PLoS One. 2014;9(7):e99682. Published 2014 Jul 3. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0099682
4 Higgins JP, Thompson SG, Deeks JJ, Altman DG. Measuring inconsistency in meta-analyses. BMJ. 2003;327(7414):557–560. doi:10.1136/bmj.327.7414.557

attributes.title: The Development of Quantifier Representations in L2 English: Lemma Transfer in Comprehension?

summary.value:
In our initial pre-registration uploaded in this project (registered on October 16, 2019), we reported that we planned three experiments (one in L1 Dutch, one in L1 English, and one in L2 English). in which we would test the role of quantifier-specific lexical information in the construction of logical representations in language comprehension. Please see this original registration plan for a description of the background, the methodology and predictions of our initial planned experiments. 

We first conducted the Dutch experiment. We started with this experiment, rather than the English experiment, for practical reasons. We can recruit Dutch-speaking participants easily among the first-year psychology students at Ghent University, who can receive course credit for their participation. We implemented and conducted the experiment online on PCIbex, which is software that we were unfamiliar with. Starting with the Dutch experiment thus allowed us to test the software for free (as we can give these participants course credit). 

In the attached file to this follow-up registration, we describe the methodology and results of this Dutch experiment in full detail. Initially (as described in our original Registration Plan), we predicted priming from ‘elke…een’ onto ‘elke…een’ (as this is a quantifier repetition) and from ‘iedere…een’ onto ‘elke…een’ (as ‘elke’ and ‘iedere’ are more-or-less synonymous to each other). Finally, we did not predict priming from ‘alle…een’ onto ‘elke…een’, as ‘alle’ and ‘elke’ differ in their inherent combinatorial properties. 

However, we observed priming of logical representations from ‘elke…een’ sentences onto ‘elke…een’ sentences and from ‘alle…een’ sentences onto ‘elke…een’ sentences. Moreover, we did not observe priming of logical representations from ‘iedere…een’ sentences onto ‘elke…een’ sentences. For full details on these results, please see the attached file. These results are thus not accordance with our predictions. 

Our results show strong individual differences between participants across all conditions. Again, this observation is described in more detail in the attached file. The presence of this much individual difference between participants across all conditions raises the question of whether the observed pattern of priming in these groups are an accurate estimation of priming effects in the population, or whether the results are distorted by random variation between participants. In order to test whether the unexpected results observed in our Dutch experiment is really due to Prime Quantifier Condition, or due to individual variance across the participants, we are going to replicate this experiment with a full within-subject design. This experiment is similar to the one we conducted, and thus still has a 2 X 3 design (Prime Condition X Prime Quantifier), but now both variables will be manipulated within subjects (whereas Prime Quantifier was manipulated between subjects in the previous experiment).  For this experiment, we will construct 6 lists of trials, in which prime quantifier and prime condition is counterbalanced. Moreover, we will recruit 180 new participants for this experiment. Further details of this experiment are described in the attached file.

We first conducted the Dutch experiment. We started with this experiment, rather than the English experiment, for practical reasons. We can recruit Dutch-speaking participants easily among the first-year psychology students at Ghent University, who can receive course credit for their participation. We implemented and conducted the experiment online on PCIbex, which is software that we were unfamiliar with. Starting with the Dutch experiment thus allowed us to test the software for free (as we can give these participants course credit). 

In the attached file to this follow-up registration, we describe the methodology and results of this Dutch experiment in full detail. Initially (as described in our original Registration Plan), we predicted priming from ‘elke…een’ onto ‘elke…een’ (as this is a quantifier repetition) and from ‘iedere…een’ onto ‘elke…een’ (as ‘elke’ and ‘iedere’ are more-or-less synonymous to each other). Finally, we did not predict priming from ‘alle…een’ onto ‘elke…een’, as ‘alle’ and ‘elke’ differ in their inherent combinatorial properties. 

However, we observed priming of logical representations from ‘elke…een’ sentences onto ‘elke…een’ sentences and from ‘alle…een’ sentences onto ‘elke…een’ sentences. Moreover, we did not observe priming of logical representations from ‘iedere…een’ sentences onto ‘elke…een’ sentences. For full details on these results, please see the attached file. These results are thus not accordance with our predictions. 

Our results show strong individual differences between participants across all conditions. Again, this observation is described in more detail in the attached file. The presence of this much individual difference between participants across all conditions raises the question of whether the observed pattern of priming in these groups are an accurate estimation of priming effects in the population, or whether the results are distorted by random variation between participants. In order to test whether the unexpected results observed in our Dutch experiment is really due to Prime Quantifier Condition, or due to individual variance across the participants, we are going to replicate this experiment with a full within-subject design. This experiment is similar to the one we conducted, and thus still has a 2 X 3 design (Prime Condition X Prime Quantifier), but now both variables will be manipulated within subjects (whereas Prime Quantifier was manipulated between subjects in the previous experiment).  For this experiment, we will construct 6 lists of trials, in which prime quantifier and prime condition is counterbalanced. Moreover, we will recruit 180 new participants for this experiment. Further details of this experiment are described in the attached file.

attributes.title: Effect of task demands on neural activity and attentional capture

summary.value:
Study Information
1.	Title: Effect of task demands on neural activity and attentional capture.

2.	Authors: Dr. Raymond Klein, Ralph Redden & Michelle Clark

3.	Description (optional)

Contingent capture (CC) proposes that an attentional control setting (ACS) becomes established for the feature critical to identifying a target, and when an irrelevant stimulus is presented (i.e. not the target) that contains the target feature, attention is involuntarily captured, but if the stimulus does not contain the target feature, attention is not captured. The purpose of this study is to investigate the difference in neural response to irrelevant stimuli that do compared to stimuli that do not contain the target feature, by measuring event related potentials (ERP) from electroencephalograph (EEG) recordings. Participants will be presented with a distractor followed by a target display, where they need to identify the target (either by the colour red or by abrupt onset) as either “X” or “=”. The distractor display will contain a red feature for one group of participants, and will be an abrupt onset distractor for the other, however all participants will be presented with a red target ACS block of trials, and an abrupt onset target ACS block of trials. ERP patterns following the distractors will be compared based on what the target ACS feature was, meaning whether the distractor matched or did not match the ACS. 

4.	Hypotheses (required)

In response to distractor stimuli containing the target feature, we hypothesize the P1 and N1 peak amplitudes will be greater when the distractor feature matches the ACS compared to when it does not. P1 and N1 components can be representative of the strength of perception, and we hypothesize that these components will indicate that the distractor is not perceived as strongly when it does not contain the target feature. These results could provide evidence as to why the contingent capture effect is observed in these paradigms. 
Design Plan

5.	Study type (required)
This study is an Experiment 

6.	Blinding (required)
6.1.	Blinding describes who is aware of the experimental manipulations within a study. Mark all that apply.
No blinding is involved in this study.

7.	Study design (required)
This study is a within and between subject 2x2 factorial design with 2 factors (distractor and target feature), each with 2 levels (colour feature or onset feature). The distractor feature is presented between-subject, the target feature is presented within-subject but separated and counterbalanced by blocks. 

8.	Randomization (optional)
The randomization involved in this study consists of the distractor-feature presentation being presented in a random order. This will be done within the experimental program on OpenSesame.

Sampling Plan

9.	Existing data (required)
Registration prior to creation of data: As of the date of submission of this research plan for preregistration, the data have not yet been collected, created, or realized. 

10.	Data collection procedures (required)
Participants will be recruited from Dalhousie University students using the university’s online study sign-up website, where participants will be able to sign up for course credit points (0.5 points for every 30 minutes of participation, as per the university’s regulations). Participants who volunteer must have normal or corrected to normal vision. Once participants are recruited, they will complete the experiment alone in the EEG lab at Dalhousie University, and the OpenSesame program as well as the EEG recording will collect data including but not limited to the EEG activity and trial reaction times and accuracy.

11.	Sample size (required)
The target sample size for this study is 20 participants. This is based on time constraints and the nature of EEG data collection, we will require a minimum of 10 participants before any data analysis is completed. 

Variables

12.	Manipulated variables (optional)
The variable being manipulated is the target feature. The target feature of the task is either the colour red or abrupt onset, and the two possible distractors will be colour or onset. The colour distractor display will consist of white dots appearing around three of four display boxes, and one set of red dots appearing around the fourth box. The onset distractor display will consist of white dots appearing around only one of the four boxes. The colour target display will consist of three white X’s and =’s appearing inside the boxes, and one red character, which is the target. The onset target will consist of one X or = appearing inside one of the boxes. There will be no pattern regarding the location of either the distractor or target displays, they will be randomly presented by the experimental program.

13.	Measured variables (required)
The variables measured in this study will consist of target identification reaction time (RT) and error rate (ER), as well as ERPs in response to distractor onset. These measures will be recorded by the opensesame program and EEG apparatus.

Analysis Plan

14.	Statistical models (required)
The predictor variables will be the distractor features and location compared to the target feature and location, and whether they are the same of different. The outcome variables will consist of RT and ER, which will be entered into a 2x2x2 repeated measures ANOVA with factors being distractor feature (colour/onset), target feature (colour/onset) and spatial cueing (cued/uncued). Cued spatial location indicates the distractor and target appear in the same box within a trial, while uncued spatial location indicates the distractor and target appear in different boxes within a trial. The significance level will be p=.05, to maintain consistency with a previously study conducted. 
The electrophysiological outcome variable will consist of ERP activity up to 1000 ms after presentation of the distractor. ERP activity from electrodes PO7/PO8 will be used to compare the timing and amplitude of the P1 and N1 ERP components of trials where the distractor contained the target feature compared to trials where the distractor did not contain the target feature, using a paired sample t-test with a significance level of 0.05. 

15.	Data exclusion (optional)
RT analysis will only include correct target identification trials, ER and ERP data analysis will include data from participants with 60% trial accuracy or greater.

attributes.title: Communicating Emotions and Needs: Social Robots As A Tool to Elicit Self-Disclosure

q1.value: Tell Me More! Assessing Interactions with Social Robots From Speech

q2.value: Guy Laban, Jean-Noel George, Val Morrison, Emily S. Cross

q3.value:
As socially assistive robots are intended to be developed and designed with the capabilities to provide meaningful support based on humans’ input, we aim to explore how social robot’s embodiment can effect on peoples’ disclosures in measurable terms, and how these disclosures differ from disclosures to humans and disembodied agents in correspondence to their level of embodiment. Hence, we are asking:
RQ: To what extent disclosures to Social Robots differ from disclosures to humans and disembodied agents?

q4.value:
While previous experiments demonstrated conflicting results, this experiment is aimed to replicate a previous experimental design and adjusting it based on the lessons that were acquired from the results. Accordingly, this study is exploratory and does not aim to answer concrete expectations. We generally expect that people will ascribe mental capacities to social robots following their human-like design and gestures (Epely & Waytz, 2010). Therefore, we propose that, in general, disclosures to humanoid social robots are genuine. Disclosures to humanoid social robots will be richer in information and will be perceived by people as such, compared to disembodied agents who lack in human-like embodiment and gestures. Nevertheless, it is proposed that disclosures to humans can elicit more information than disclosures to robots and agents considering their natural human embodiment while being perceived as such. However, we consider that disclosures to humanoid social robots can overcome some of the natural limitations of self-disclosure. 

Accordingly, we aim to explore how these disclosures differ between the three agents through speech. Moreover, we would like to explore how different assessment methods could provide further evidence for the differences in interactions and disclosures between the three agents through speech.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value: Since the experiment design is within-subjects, all of the participants will take part in all of the manipulations. However, the order of the treatment will be randomised and neither the human-subjects nor the experimenter will know the order of the treatment until the participant will take part in it.

question.value:
A within-subjects design with three treatments will be conducted in a voice recording lab. In a randomized order, all of the participants will interact with three agents: (1) a humanoid social robot (NAO, SoftBank Robotics), (2) a human agent (the corresponding experimenter), or (3) a disembodied agent (voice assistant – Google Home Mini).

 In a randomized order and allocation to an agent treatment, all of the participants will be asked about three topics: (1) work and life balance (one question about one’s financial situation, and one question about spare time and hobbies), (2) relationships and society (one question about one’s closest relationships, and one question about socializing habits), (3) physical and mental health (one question about habits of sustaining physical health, and one question about habits of sustaining/treating mental health). The questions within each topic will be randomly ordered and will be communicated by the agent treatment that will be randomly assigned to the topic treatment. The interactions between the participants and the agents (humanoid social robot /human /disembodied agent) will be recorded for analysis purposes, extracting content and acoustic features from the audio files.  These will be anonymized and encrypted. 

All the questions are the same across the agent treatments (see Variables section), whereas agents differ following their level of embodiment and the demonstrated gestures that correspond with their embodiment (see Variables section).
The experiment will be administered using a “formR” application (the experiment sheet will be uploaded to the project page on OSF) that randomized the treatments automatically. After each interaction participants will be requested to evaluate the agent in terms of experience (the ability to sense and feel) and agency (the ability to plan and act) after being introduced to these terms. Moreover, after each interaction participants will evaluate their subjective disclosure to each of the agents via an adjusted version of the sub-scale of work and studies disclosure in Jourard's Self-Disclosure Questionnaire (Jourard, 1971). Finally, after all of the interactions participants will be requested to complete a short questionnaire, reporting demographic parameters (including their age, biological sex, gender, level of education, nationality, previous experience with robots, and if English is their native language), their periodic stress on the perceived stress scale (Cohen, Kamarck, & Mermelstein, 1983), and will be asked to rank their extraversion score on 8 extraversion items of the Mini-Markers Big Five personality scale (Saucier, 1994). 
Data collection is planned to take place at the Institute of Neuroscience and Psychology of the University of Glasgow, from Tuesday, 25/02/20, testing 10 participants each day between 09:00 to 17:00. Each interaction should take no longer than five minutes, whereas the experiment in total should take no longer than 30 minutes.
The experimenter(s) will be seated near a desk outside of the recording room, where the participant cannot see him, yet there is a window between the recording room and the experimenter desk in case the participant will need to get the experiment attention (see Lab_settings.jpg; more pictures of the lab and the settings will be uploaded to OSF if needed after data collection). The recording room is completely soundproof.

q9.value: The order of treatments will be randomised by the “formR” application that was made for the experiment.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Eligibility criteria were individuals who had English as their first language and were aged 16 and over. Two emails were sent to relevant candidates (first on 20/02/20 to 2975 potential candidates, second on 21/02/20) and an advert that includes the same information was published at the participant subjects-pool website on 20/02/20 (the script of the advert is attached). Potential participants can independently book their participation in the study in one of the available testing slots (about 14 slots each day) from Tuesday, 25/02/20, between 09:00 to 17:00. Participants will need to attend independently to the waiting room of the Institute of Neuroscience and Psychology of the University of Glasgow and will be escorted to the lab. Participants will be compensated with 3 GBP for their participation, or 2 research participation credits (for psychology students who attend the University of Glasgow).

q13.value: Our target sample size is 103 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 110 participants, assuming that not all will complete the task in the right way or might experience technical disruptions in the recordings. If the data collection pace will permit, we might consider recruiting more than 110 participants.

q14.value:
Priori power calculations using G*power software (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007; Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, & Lang, 2009) details that for a small to medium effect size a sample size of 103 units should be appropriate (see G*power input and output below). 
F tests - MANOVA: Repeated measures, within factors
Options:	Pillai V, O'Brien-Shieh Algorithm
Analysis:	A priori: Compute required sample size 
Input:	Effect size f	=	0.1005038
	α err prob	=	0.05
	Power (1-β err prob)	=	0.80
	Number of groups	=	1
	Number of measurements	=	30
	Corr among rep measures	=	0
Output:	Noncentrality parameter λ	=	31.2121327
	Critical F	=	1.6206668
	Numerator df	=	29.0000000
	Denominator df	=	74.0000000
	Total sample size	=	103
	Actual power	=	0.8009988
	Pillai V	=	0.2325582

question.value:
Agents - The three agents communicated the same exact questions using different visual and verbal cues or gestures that corresponded appropriately to their embodiment. The order of the treatments was randomized across the participants.

Humanoid Social Robot: This treatment was manipulated using the robot NAO (Softbank Robotics), a human-like robot who can communicate with humans via speech but can also demonstrate several cognitive-like cues using motion, gaze, and body gestures. NAO communicated with participants in this study via the Wizard of Oz (WoZ) technique controlled by the experimenter on a PC laptop. When a participant is answering to NAO’s questions, NAO will be directing gaze to the participant, nodding with his head every few seconds, and the breathing functionality will be activated to reduce the variance in the embodiment between the conditions of the humanoid social robot and the human agent. These animations were made before conducting the experiment using SoftBank Robotics’ Choreograph software. When NAO was speaking to participants his movements were self-initiated based on NAO’s demo software.

Human-Agent: This treatment consists of the experimenter as an elicitor. This treatment was manipulated by the natural agent’s looks, voice, and gestures (e.g., nodding). The human gestures were not planned and followed his natural embodiment. However, the human agent was instructed not to speak when participants were answering questions.
Disembodied Agent: This treatment is manipulated using the “Google home mini”. A voice assistant is a software in a speaker, and as such it has a minimal physical presence and it is disembodied – not demonstrating any sort of visual cues and it’s verbal cues are limited to clear manifest ones (“I understand”, “Okay, I see”) rather than natural implicit ones (e.g., “ahh”, “amm”). The voice assistant was also controlled by the experimenter via the WoZ technique, using Bluetooth technology via an Android tablet.

The topic of conversation – While not being a manipulated variable, these are reported here for the sake of transparency as these were meaningful elements in the experiment’s manipulation and should be considered when the manipulation is discussed. These are general, every day topics that were chosen to elicit disclosure among the participants. The order of the topics and their allocation to an agent will be randomized. The order of the questions within each topic of conversation will also be randomized. The questions were face validated with a native (British) English speaker to make sure that they correspond to the informal nature of a chat. 

Work and life balance: One question about one’s financial situation, and question about spare time and hobbies.

Relationships and society: One question about one’s closest relationships, and one question about socializing habits

Physical and mental health: One question about habits of sustaining physical health, and one question about habits of sustaining/treating mental health.

Measurements were collected using self-reported questionnaires that were operated on a “formR” application (the sheet will be uploaded to OSF), were extracted from the audio recordings using different computational methods that were performed using Python (Python notebook with the scripts will be uploaded to OSF), and were manually coded by the researchers. 

Self-reported:

Agency and Experience: After each interaction participants will be requested to evaluate the agent in terms of experience (the ability to sense and feel) and agency (the ability to plan and act) after being introduced to these terms. Each of the concepts will be evaluated by the participants using a 0 to 100 rating bar. 

Perceived Self Disclosure: After each interaction, participants will be requested to report their level of perceived self-disclosure via the sub-scale of work and studies disclosure in Jourard's Self-Disclosure Questionnaire (1971). This questionnaire was adapted and adjusted for the context of the study, addressing the statements to the topics of the interactions. The measurement included ten self-reported items in which participants reported the extent to which they disclosed information to one of the agents on a scale of one (not at all) to seven (to a great extent). 

Demographics: After all of the interactions participants will be requested to complete a short questionnaire, reporting demographic parameters including their age, biological sex, gender, level of education, nationality, job, previous experience with robots, and if English is their native language. 

Perceived stress scale: Then, participants will be requested to report their periodic stress on ten statement items of the perceived stress scale (Cohen, Kamarck, & Mermelstein, 1983), evaluating these on a scale of 1 (never) to five (very often). 

Extraversion: Participants will be asked to rank their extraversion score on a scale of 1 (not at all) to 5 (very applicable) on the 8 extraversion items of the Mini-Markers Big Five personality scale (Saucier, 1994).

Extracted from the recordings:

Some of the measurements that will be extracted from the recordings are text-based and others are audio-based. For more information about the processing of the recordings see “Indices”.

Text-based:

Length of the Disclosure: The volume of disclosure in terms of the number of words per disclosure.

Compound Sentiment: The compound sentiment evaluates a disclosure sentiment from negative (-1) to positive (+1), based on the calculated sentiment score (see Hutto & Gilbert, 2014).

Sentimentality: The ratio of overall demonstrated sentiment in each disclosure.
 
After collecting the data, we might consider extracting other text-based measurements from the recordings using various Python packages, e.g., emotionality and tone.
 
Audio-based:
Duration: The duration of each interaction in seconds.
Pitch: in Hertz.
Intensity: the loudness of the sound wave in decibels (dB).
Harmonicity: the degree of acoustic periodicity in dB.
Energy: air pressure in the voice.

After collecting the data, we might consider extracting other acoustic features (e.g., jitter and shitter) and other audio-based measurements from the recordings using various Python packages (e.g., pre-processed valence and arousal metrics from voice). 

Manual Content Analysis:
Inter-rater reliability scores will be produced for each of the measurements if will be used in the analysis.  

Sensitivity: The researchers will manually code if a disclosure contains sensitive information (1 for a disclosure that includes sensitive information, 0 for not including sensitive information). Sensitive information is defined according to the European Commission’s GDPR statement: “personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs; trade-union membership; genetic data, biometric data processed solely to identify a human being; health-related data; data concerning a person’s sex life or sexual orientation” (https://ec.europa.eu/info/law/law-topic/data-protection/reform/rules-business-and-organisations/legal-grounds-processing-data/sensitive-data/what-personal-data-considered-sensitive_en).
In a broader context, the researchers will pay attention to code disclosures as sensitive if those include any extent of information that describes an event or situation that is described as personal, intimate, uncomfortable, or private.

Asking for response: The researchers will manually code if during a disclosure a participant verbally approach the agent for a response or for his attention (1 for a disclosure that includes an ask for a response, 0 for not). E.g., “you know what I mean?”, “what do you think”, “…so you see…”, etc.

Self-reported: 

Mean index will be formed to the perceived self-disclosure scale (individual index for each agent in a wide dataset, and if a long dataset will be used for some complimentary analysis, one index for all agents), perceived stress scale, and for the extraversion scale.
For the extraversion scale, we might check other methods of data wrangling to get a better representative score of extraversion-introversion following the scale’s instructions (Saucier, 1994).

Extracted from the recordings:

Text-based:

The recordings will be processed using a speech recognition package for Python, with a speech recognition engine API of Google Cloud to Python. The text will be then fixed and transcribed by the researchers to make sure that it corresponds to the recordings.
Length of the Disclosure: The number of words per disclosure was extracted from the text using a simple “len()” command on Python. 

Compound Sentiment: Using Vader for Python (see Hutto & Gilbert, 2014), the disclosures will be measured to determine their overall sentiment in terms of positive, neutral, and negative sentiment. The Vader package produces 3 scores with a value between 0 to 1 for each disclosure: positive, neutral, and negative. Each score represents the ratio of keywords that were identified as positive/neutral (non-sentimental)/negative based on a sentiment analysis corpus (see Hutto & Gilbert, 2014). The compound score represents the overall compound score of sentiment on a -1 (negative) to 1 (positive) scale. 

Sentimentality: The ratio of overall demonstrated sentiment in each disclosure was calculated based on the combined scores of Vader’s (see Hutto & Gilbert, 2014) individual positive and negative sentiment scores.

Audio-based:

Voice acoustics features will be extracted and processed using Parselmouth (Jadoul, Thompson, & de Boer, 2018), a Python library for Praat (Boersma & Weenink, 2018) software and method for audio/acoustic signal processing from voice. We plan to use the mean value for the extracted features of pitch (in hertz), harmonicity (in dB), and intensity (in dB) as a representative score. However, we might consider using other indices as, for example, the minimum and maximum scores, and mean within the inter-quartile values for exploring other dimensions of these measurements in our analysis. Energy will be measured as the square of the amplitude multiplied by the duration of the sound.

Doubly multivariate analysis of variance will be conducted to determine whether a difference in disclosure will emerge between the agents, measured in terms of perceived (subjective) self – disclosure and observed disclosure (including length of the disclosure, sentimentality, compound sentiment, pitch, harmonicity, intensity, energy, and duration of speech). Other measurements of disclosure might be included in the final model according to any further decisions that will be taken when pre-processing the data. Pairwise comparison and posthoc analysis with Bonferroni correction will be conducted to evaluate the differences between the treatments. 

We will run this model again controlling for perceived stress scale and extroversion. We might also control for the topic of conversation using two dummy variables. 
If needed, we will consider testing another doubly multivariate analysis of variance, with the same outcome variables and the topic of conversation as treatment level, to explore the role of the topic of conversations. 

We will check for univariate differences in experience and agency between the agents.
We will test for correlations between the measurements, especially looking at individual relationships between the measurements of disclosure with the measurements of agency and experience, stratified according to the agent treatment. 

We might consider other analytical models in addition to the ones discussed here. If this will be the case, we will update on any further analysis and share the relevant code accordingly.

q20.value:
For producing relevant visualizations easily, we will wrangle the wide dataset that will be used for the analysis to produce a long data-set that is more convenient for visualization data.

We might also control for the topic of conversation using two dummy variables.
 
We could transform some other categorical variables to dummies, however, cannot report of any of those at the moment.

Also, look at the "Indices" section for more information about other transformations.

q21.value:
We would use p-values as criteria to make inferences unless otherwise is specified. We don't expect for using other criteria values. 

For reliability of the scales we will use Cronbach Alpha as criteria, and Kripendors Alpha for inter-rater reliability for measurements that are produced from the manual content analysis.

q22.value: First, the quality of the recordings will be checked for noise. Recordings with technical failures or noise will be dropped. Then that data will be inspected after the pre-processing phase for outliers and these will be reported. However, we do not expect to exclude these from our analysis.

q23.value: We do not expect cases of missing data because of the controlled nature of the lab experiment. However, in the case of missing data, we will drop the case.

registration_responses.q1: Tell Me More! Assessing Interactions with Social Robots From Speech
registration_responses.q2: Guy Laban, Jean-Noel George, Val Morrison, Emily S. Cross
registration_responses.q3:
As socially assistive robots are intended to be developed and designed with the capabilities to provide meaningful support based on humans’ input, we aim to explore how social robot’s embodiment can effect on peoples’ disclosures in measurable terms, and how these disclosures differ from disclosures to humans and disembodied agents in correspondence to their level of embodiment. Hence, we are asking:
RQ: To what extent disclosures to Social Robots differ from disclosures to humans and disembodied agents?
registration_responses.q4:
While previous experiments demonstrated conflicting results, this experiment is aimed to replicate a previous experimental design and adjusting it based on the lessons that were acquired from the results. Accordingly, this study is exploratory and does not aim to answer concrete expectations. We generally expect that people will ascribe mental capacities to social robots following their human-like design and gestures (Epely & Waytz, 2010). Therefore, we propose that, in general, disclosures to humanoid social robots are genuine. Disclosures to humanoid social robots will be richer in information and will be perceived by people as such, compared to disembodied agents who lack in human-like embodiment and gestures. Nevertheless, it is proposed that disclosures to humans can elicit more information than disclosures to robots and agents considering their natural human embodiment while being perceived as such. However, we consider that disclosures to humanoid social robots can overcome some of the natural limitations of self-disclosure. 

Accordingly, we aim to explore how these disclosures differ between the three agents through speech. Moreover, we would like to explore how different assessment methods could provide further evidence for the differences in interactions and disclosures between the three agents through speech.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
registration_responses.q7: Since the experiment design is within-subjects, all of the participants will take part in all of the manipulations. However, the order of the treatment will be randomised and neither the human-subjects nor the experimenter will know the order of the treatment until the participant will take part in it.
registration_responses.q9: The order of treatments will be randomised by the “formR” application that was made for the experiment.

registration_responses.q8.question:
A within-subjects design with three treatments will be conducted in a voice recording lab. In a randomized order, all of the participants will interact with three agents: (1) a humanoid social robot (NAO, SoftBank Robotics), (2) a human agent (the corresponding experimenter), or (3) a disembodied agent (voice assistant – Google Home Mini).

 In a randomized order and allocation to an agent treatment, all of the participants will be asked about three topics: (1) work and life balance (one question about one’s financial situation, and one question about spare time and hobbies), (2) relationships and society (one question about one’s closest relationships, and one question about socializing habits), (3) physical and mental health (one question about habits of sustaining physical health, and one question about habits of sustaining/treating mental health). The questions within each topic will be randomly ordered and will be communicated by the agent treatment that will be randomly assigned to the topic treatment. The interactions between the participants and the agents (humanoid social robot /human /disembodied agent) will be recorded for analysis purposes, extracting content and acoustic features from the audio files.  These will be anonymized and encrypted. 

All the questions are the same across the agent treatments (see Variables section), whereas agents differ following their level of embodiment and the demonstrated gestures that correspond with their embodiment (see Variables section).
The experiment will be administered using a “formR” application (the experiment sheet will be uploaded to the project page on OSF) that randomized the treatments automatically. After each interaction participants will be requested to evaluate the agent in terms of experience (the ability to sense and feel) and agency (the ability to plan and act) after being introduced to these terms. Moreover, after each interaction participants will evaluate their subjective disclosure to each of the agents via an adjusted version of the sub-scale of work and studies disclosure in Jourard's Self-Disclosure Questionnaire (Jourard, 1971). Finally, after all of the interactions participants will be requested to complete a short questionnaire, reporting demographic parameters (including their age, biological sex, gender, level of education, nationality, previous experience with robots, and if English is their native language), their periodic stress on the perceived stress scale (Cohen, Kamarck, & Mermelstein, 1983), and will be asked to rank their extraversion score on 8 extraversion items of the Mini-Markers Big Five personality scale (Saucier, 1994). 
Data collection is planned to take place at the Institute of Neuroscience and Psychology of the University of Glasgow, from Tuesday, 25/02/20, testing 10 participants each day between 09:00 to 17:00. Each interaction should take no longer than five minutes, whereas the experiment in total should take no longer than 30 minutes.
The experimenter(s) will be seated near a desk outside of the recording room, where the participant cannot see him, yet there is a window between the recording room and the experimenter desk in case the participant will need to get the experiment attention (see Lab_settings.jpg; more pictures of the lab and the settings will be uploaded to OSF if needed after data collection). The recording room is completely soundproof.
registration_responses.q12.question: Eligibility criteria were individuals who had English as their first language and were aged 16 and over. Two emails were sent to relevant candidates (first on 20/02/20 to 2975 potential candidates, second on 21/02/20) and an advert that includes the same information was published at the participant subjects-pool website on 20/02/20 (the script of the advert is attached). Potential participants can independently book their participation in the study in one of the available testing slots (about 14 slots each day) from Tuesday, 25/02/20, between 09:00 to 17:00. Participants will need to attend independently to the waiting room of the Institute of Neuroscience and Psychology of the University of Glasgow and will be escorted to the lab. Participants will be compensated with 3 GBP for their participation, or 2 research participation credits (for psychology students who attend the University of Glasgow).
registration_responses.q16.question:
Agents - The three agents communicated the same exact questions using different visual and verbal cues or gestures that corresponded appropriately to their embodiment. The order of the treatments was randomized across the participants.

Humanoid Social Robot: This treatment was manipulated using the robot NAO (Softbank Robotics), a human-like robot who can communicate with humans via speech but can also demonstrate several cognitive-like cues using motion, gaze, and body gestures. NAO communicated with participants in this study via the Wizard of Oz (WoZ) technique controlled by the experimenter on a PC laptop. When a participant is answering to NAO’s questions, NAO will be directing gaze to the participant, nodding with his head every few seconds, and the breathing functionality will be activated to reduce the variance in the embodiment between the conditions of the humanoid social robot and the human agent. These animations were made before conducting the experiment using SoftBank Robotics’ Choreograph software. When NAO was speaking to participants his movements were self-initiated based on NAO’s demo software.

Human-Agent: This treatment consists of the experimenter as an elicitor. This treatment was manipulated by the natural agent’s looks, voice, and gestures (e.g., nodding). The human gestures were not planned and followed his natural embodiment. However, the human agent was instructed not to speak when participants were answering questions.
Disembodied Agent: This treatment is manipulated using the “Google home mini”. A voice assistant is a software in a speaker, and as such it has a minimal physical presence and it is disembodied – not demonstrating any sort of visual cues and it’s verbal cues are limited to clear manifest ones (“I understand”, “Okay, I see”) rather than natural implicit ones (e.g., “ahh”, “amm”). The voice assistant was also controlled by the experimenter via the WoZ technique, using Bluetooth technology via an Android tablet.

The topic of conversation – While not being a manipulated variable, these are reported here for the sake of transparency as these were meaningful elements in the experiment’s manipulation and should be considered when the manipulation is discussed. These are general, every day topics that were chosen to elicit disclosure among the participants. The order of the topics and their allocation to an agent will be randomized. The order of the questions within each topic of conversation will also be randomized. The questions were face validated with a native (British) English speaker to make sure that they correspond to the informal nature of a chat. 

Work and life balance: One question about one’s financial situation, and question about spare time and hobbies.

Relationships and society: One question about one’s closest relationships, and one question about socializing habits

Physical and mental health: One question about habits of sustaining physical health, and one question about habits of sustaining/treating mental health.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Measurements were collected using self-reported questionnaires that were operated on a “formR” application (the sheet will be uploaded to OSF), were extracted from the audio recordings using different computational methods that were performed using Python (Python notebook with the scripts will be uploaded to OSF), and were manually coded by the researchers. 

Self-reported:

Agency and Experience: After each interaction participants will be requested to evaluate the agent in terms of experience (the ability to sense and feel) and agency (the ability to plan and act) after being introduced to these terms. Each of the concepts will be evaluated by the participants using a 0 to 100 rating bar. 

Perceived Self Disclosure: After each interaction, participants will be requested to report their level of perceived self-disclosure via the sub-scale of work and studies disclosure in Jourard's Self-Disclosure Questionnaire (1971). This questionnaire was adapted and adjusted for the context of the study, addressing the statements to the topics of the interactions. The measurement included ten self-reported items in which participants reported the extent to which they disclosed information to one of the agents on a scale of one (not at all) to seven (to a great extent). 

Demographics: After all of the interactions participants will be requested to complete a short questionnaire, reporting demographic parameters including their age, biological sex, gender, level of education, nationality, job, previous experience with robots, and if English is their native language. 

Perceived stress scale: Then, participants will be requested to report their periodic stress on ten statement items of the perceived stress scale (Cohen, Kamarck, & Mermelstein, 1983), evaluating these on a scale of 1 (never) to five (very often). 

Extraversion: Participants will be asked to rank their extraversion score on a scale of 1 (not at all) to 5 (very applicable) on the 8 extraversion items of the Mini-Markers Big Five personality scale (Saucier, 1994).

Extracted from the recordings:

Some of the measurements that will be extracted from the recordings are text-based and others are audio-based. For more information about the processing of the recordings see “Indices”.

Text-based:

Length of the Disclosure: The volume of disclosure in terms of the number of words per disclosure.

Compound Sentiment: The compound sentiment evaluates a disclosure sentiment from negative (-1) to positive (+1), based on the calculated sentiment score (see Hutto & Gilbert, 2014).

Sentimentality: The ratio of overall demonstrated sentiment in each disclosure.
 
After collecting the data, we might consider extracting other text-based measurements from the recordings using various Python packages, e.g., emotionality and tone.
 
Audio-based:
Duration: The duration of each interaction in seconds.
Pitch: in Hertz.
Intensity: the loudness of the sound wave in decibels (dB).
Harmonicity: the degree of acoustic periodicity in dB.
Energy: air pressure in the voice.

After collecting the data, we might consider extracting other acoustic features (e.g., jitter and shitter) and other audio-based measurements from the recordings using various Python packages (e.g., pre-processed valence and arousal metrics from voice). 

Manual Content Analysis:
Inter-rater reliability scores will be produced for each of the measurements if will be used in the analysis.  

Sensitivity: The researchers will manually code if a disclosure contains sensitive information (1 for a disclosure that includes sensitive information, 0 for not including sensitive information). Sensitive information is defined according to the European Commission’s GDPR statement: “personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs; trade-union membership; genetic data, biometric data processed solely to identify a human being; health-related data; data concerning a person’s sex life or sexual orientation” (https://ec.europa.eu/info/law/law-topic/data-protection/reform/rules-business-and-organisations/legal-grounds-processing-data/sensitive-data/what-personal-data-considered-sensitive_en).
In a broader context, the researchers will pay attention to code disclosures as sensitive if those include any extent of information that describes an event or situation that is described as personal, intimate, uncomfortable, or private.

Asking for response: The researchers will manually code if during a disclosure a participant verbally approach the agent for a response or for his attention (1 for a disclosure that includes an ask for a response, 0 for not). E.g., “you know what I mean?”, “what do you think”, “…so you see…”, etc.
registration_responses.q18.question:
Self-reported: 

Mean index will be formed to the perceived self-disclosure scale (individual index for each agent in a wide dataset, and if a long dataset will be used for some complimentary analysis, one index for all agents), perceived stress scale, and for the extraversion scale.
For the extraversion scale, we might check other methods of data wrangling to get a better representative score of extraversion-introversion following the scale’s instructions (Saucier, 1994).

Extracted from the recordings:

Text-based:

The recordings will be processed using a speech recognition package for Python, with a speech recognition engine API of Google Cloud to Python. The text will be then fixed and transcribed by the researchers to make sure that it corresponds to the recordings.
Length of the Disclosure: The number of words per disclosure was extracted from the text using a simple “len()” command on Python. 

Compound Sentiment: Using Vader for Python (see Hutto & Gilbert, 2014), the disclosures will be measured to determine their overall sentiment in terms of positive, neutral, and negative sentiment. The Vader package produces 3 scores with a value between 0 to 1 for each disclosure: positive, neutral, and negative. Each score represents the ratio of keywords that were identified as positive/neutral (non-sentimental)/negative based on a sentiment analysis corpus (see Hutto & Gilbert, 2014). The compound score represents the overall compound score of sentiment on a -1 (negative) to 1 (positive) scale. 

Sentimentality: The ratio of overall demonstrated sentiment in each disclosure was calculated based on the combined scores of Vader’s (see Hutto & Gilbert, 2014) individual positive and negative sentiment scores.

Audio-based:

Voice acoustics features will be extracted and processed using Parselmouth (Jadoul, Thompson, & de Boer, 2018), a Python library for Praat (Boersma & Weenink, 2018) software and method for audio/acoustic signal processing from voice. We plan to use the mean value for the extracted features of pitch (in hertz), harmonicity (in dB), and intensity (in dB) as a representative score. However, we might consider using other indices as, for example, the minimum and maximum scores, and mean within the inter-quartile values for exploring other dimensions of these measurements in our analysis. Energy will be measured as the square of the amplitude multiplied by the duration of the sound.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Doubly multivariate analysis of variance will be conducted to determine whether a difference in disclosure will emerge between the agents, measured in terms of perceived (subjective) self – disclosure and observed disclosure (including length of the disclosure, sentimentality, compound sentiment, pitch, harmonicity, intensity, energy, and duration of speech). Other measurements of disclosure might be included in the final model according to any further decisions that will be taken when pre-processing the data. Pairwise comparison and posthoc analysis with Bonferroni correction will be conducted to evaluate the differences between the treatments. 

We will run this model again controlling for perceived stress scale and extroversion. We might also control for the topic of conversation using two dummy variables. 
If needed, we will consider testing another doubly multivariate analysis of variance, with the same outcome variables and the topic of conversation as treatment level, to explore the role of the topic of conversations. 

We will check for univariate differences in experience and agency between the agents.
We will test for correlations between the measurements, especially looking at individual relationships between the measurements of disclosure with the measurements of agency and experience, stratified according to the agent treatment. 

We might consider other analytical models in addition to the ones discussed here. If this will be the case, we will update on any further analysis and share the relevant code accordingly.

attributes.title: The Real-Time Relation between Shame and Alcohol Use

q1.value: •	The Real-Time Relation between Shame and Alcohol Use

q2.value: Macey Rose Schallert, Madison Feil, Kevin King

q3.value: Feelings of shame are hypothesized to predict episodes of alcohol misuse. Prior studies suggested that shame motivated drinking may be especially relevant for men because they are more likely to drink to cope with negative emotions or perceived failures of masculinity. However, prior studies have investigated the relations between shame and alcohol use using global self-report measures, rather than testing within-person associations. In other words, these studies have shown that people who experience more shame also report more alcohol use, but it is unclear whether when people experience shame, they also report drinking more. We used Ecological Momentary Assessment (EMA) to measure both within- and between-person associations between feelings of shame and daily alcohol use. Further, we aimed to test whether these relations are stronger among males relative to females

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Higher levels of average shame over the EMA period will be associated with higher levels of average drinking over the same period.

Hypothesis 2: Higher levels of average shame over the EMA period will be associated with higher levels of average unplanned drinking over the same period.

Hypothesis 3: Daily pre-drinking shame will predict total daily drinking on the same day.

Hypothesis 4: Daily pre-drinking shame will predict daily unplanned drinking on the same day.

Hypotheses 5-8: In all previous hypotheses (1-4), gender will moderate the effect such that males will have a stronger effect of shame on drinking.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The present study consists of a sample of undergraduate students from a university in the Pacific Northwest (expected n = 132) enrolled in an introductory psychology course. Participants went through an initial screening to determine eligibility for the current study. In order to be granted eligibility, participants were required to be a student at the university and drink on an at-least weekly basis. Each participant was granted course credit for their participation in one or both parts of the study. Following an in-lab baseline survey of demographics and personality, participants were oriented to the EMA procedures and went on to complete five mini cell-phone surveys a day for two weekends (Thursday-Sunday) beginning Thursday night following the in-lab portion of the study. These surveys were sent randomly within five set intervals from 9am to 9pm. Participants could delay each survey up to one hour. Questions on these surveys asked participants about their current mood, recent impulsive behaviors, and use of substances the previous day.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: This sample consists of undergraduate students in the Pacific Northwest. The undergraduate students were compensated with course credit for their participation in the study. Participants complete 8 days of cell-phone mini-surveys over the course of two weeks, starting Thursday and going to Sunday, then the next week again from Thursday to Sunday (4 days for each week, and on each day, they received 5 surveys distributed at random times). The sample size (n) for this will be finalized by March 2020.

q13.value: We currently have an n of 125, but we expect an n of 132 when data collection has commenced in March 2020.

q15.value: Data collection is ongoing. We expect to collect data from 7 more participants, making our expected n = 132 by the end of data collection in March 2020.

question.value:
Predictors:
Shame: Shame was measured on a visual analog slider bar at every assessment on a scale from “not at all” to “very much”. These responses are scored on a scale of 1 to 100 based on where the participant placed their answer on the slider bar. A measure of average shame will be calculated by taking the mean of these momentary scores from all recorded observations for each participant. Daily pre-drinking shame will be calculated by taking the mean of reports from any time point before they reported drinking.

Outcomes:
Alcohol use: Participants were asked in the first survey of each day how many drinks they consumed the night before and when they began drinking. For our measure of total daily drinking, we will use this simple count of self-reported drinks. Average drinking was calculated by taking the mean of self-reported drinks across the entire study period.

Unplanned drinking: Participants were asked in a mid-day survey how many drinks they expected to drink that night. Participants who reported “not likely” to drink for the immediate evening, but then reported alcohol use the following morning will be used to calculate unplanned drinking. Average unplanned drinking use was calculated by taking the mean of all days for which an unplanned drinks score can be calculated.

Covariates:
Biological sex: The self-reported sex will be coded on a binary scale (1 =  male, 0 = female) for each participant and will be used as a moderator for the analysis of hypotheses 5-8.

Race: Self-reported race will be coded on a binary scale (1 = white, 0 = non-white) and will be included as a covariate on each analysis.

Age: Self-reported age will be included as a covariate

Guilt: Guilt was measured on a visual analog slider bar at every assessment on a scale from “not at all” to “very much”. These responses are scored on a scale of 1 to 100 based on where the participant placed their answer on the slider bar. 

We will report all models with and without the covariates to estimate their impact.

We will use generalized estimating equations (GEE) with an unstructured correlation matrix and compare against an exchangeable matrix to decide which one best fits the data. Because drinking is a count, we will compare a variety of count distributions against a normal distribution to test which best fits our data. We will use these models to test the association between our predictors: average shame (H1 and H2) and daily pre-drinking shame (H3 and H4), and our outcomes: average drinking (H1), average unplanned drinking (H2), total daily drinking (H3), and daily unplanned drinking (H4). For all of our analyses, biological sex (1 = male, 0 = female) will be included as a moderator (H5-H8).

q20.value: We will grand mean center person-level average shame. Daily pre-drinking shame will be centered within-person.

q21.value: We will use a standard p < .05 criterion for determining whether GEE provided evidence that average and momentary shame are significant predictors for average and daily total and unplanned drinking.

q22.value: We will exclude data from participants who report no alcohol use at baseline. We will also exclude data from participants who have a low number of responses (participants who completed fewer than 3 days worth of assessments or 15 assessments total will be excluded).

q23.value: At the average level, missing observations will be treated as missing at random. At the daily level, any observation will be excluded that is missing either the predictor or that outcome. Otherwise, GEEs can account for missing data of each participant with any EMA data by computing estimates.

q24.value: We will compare the current analysis plan above regarding unplanned drinks to an analysis where we take the difference of reported, planned drinks and actual drinks consumed.
