registration_responses.q15: Data collection is ongoing. We expect to collect data from 7 more participants, making our expected n = 132 by the end of data collection in March 2020.
registration_responses.q20: We will grand mean center person-level average shame. Daily pre-drinking shame will be centered within-person.
registration_responses.q21: We will use a standard p < .05 criterion for determining whether GEE provided evidence that average and momentary shame are significant predictors for average and daily total and unplanned drinking.
registration_responses.q22: We will exclude data from participants who report no alcohol use at baseline. We will also exclude data from participants who have a low number of responses (participants who completed fewer than 3 days worth of assessments or 15 assessments total will be excluded).
registration_responses.q23: At the average level, missing observations will be treated as missing at random. At the daily level, any observation will be excluded that is missing either the predictor or that outcome. Otherwise, GEEs can account for missing data of each participant with any EMA data by computing estimates.
registration_responses.q24: We will compare the current analysis plan above regarding unplanned drinks to an analysis where we take the difference of reported, planned drinks and actual drinks consumed.
registration_responses.q8.question: The present study consists of a sample of undergraduate students from a university in the Pacific Northwest (expected n = 132) enrolled in an introductory psychology course. Participants went through an initial screening to determine eligibility for the current study. In order to be granted eligibility, participants were required to be a student at the university and drink on an at-least weekly basis. Each participant was granted course credit for their participation in one or both parts of the study. Following an in-lab baseline survey of demographics and personality, participants were oriented to the EMA procedures and went on to complete five mini cell-phone surveys a day for two weekends (Thursday-Sunday) beginning Thursday night following the in-lab portion of the study. These surveys were sent randomly within five set intervals from 9am to 9pm. Participants could delay each survey up to one hour. Questions on these surveys asked participants about their current mood, recent impulsive behaviors, and use of substances the previous day.
registration_responses.q12.question: This sample consists of undergraduate students in the Pacific Northwest. The undergraduate students were compensated with course credit for their participation in the study. Participants complete 8 days of cell-phone mini-surveys over the course of two weeks, starting Thursday and going to Sunday, then the next week again from Thursday to Sunday (4 days for each week, and on each day, they received 5 surveys distributed at random times). The sample size (n) for this will be finalized by March 2020.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Predictors:
Shame: Shame was measured on a visual analog slider bar at every assessment on a scale from “not at all” to “very much”. These responses are scored on a scale of 1 to 100 based on where the participant placed their answer on the slider bar. A measure of average shame will be calculated by taking the mean of these momentary scores from all recorded observations for each participant. Daily pre-drinking shame will be calculated by taking the mean of reports from any time point before they reported drinking.

Outcomes:
Alcohol use: Participants were asked in the first survey of each day how many drinks they consumed the night before and when they began drinking. For our measure of total daily drinking, we will use this simple count of self-reported drinks. Average drinking was calculated by taking the mean of self-reported drinks across the entire study period.

Unplanned drinking: Participants were asked in a mid-day survey how many drinks they expected to drink that night. Participants who reported “not likely” to drink for the immediate evening, but then reported alcohol use the following morning will be used to calculate unplanned drinking. Average unplanned drinking use was calculated by taking the mean of all days for which an unplanned drinks score can be calculated.

Covariates:
Biological sex: The self-reported sex will be coded on a binary scale (1 =  male, 0 = female) for each participant and will be used as a moderator for the analysis of hypotheses 5-8.

Race: Self-reported race will be coded on a binary scale (1 = white, 0 = non-white) and will be included as a covariate on each analysis.

Age: Self-reported age will be included as a covariate

Guilt: Guilt was measured on a visual analog slider bar at every assessment on a scale from “not at all” to “very much”. These responses are scored on a scale of 1 to 100 based on where the participant placed their answer on the slider bar. 

We will report all models with and without the covariates to estimate their impact.
registration_responses.q19.question: We will use generalized estimating equations (GEE) with an unstructured correlation matrix and compare against an exchangeable matrix to decide which one best fits the data. Because drinking is a count, we will compare a variety of count distributions against a normal distribution to test which best fits our data. We will use these models to test the association between our predictors: average shame (H1 and H2) and daily pre-drinking shame (H3 and H4), and our outcomes: average drinking (H1), average unplanned drinking (H2), total daily drinking (H3), and daily unplanned drinking (H4). For all of our analyses, biological sex (1 = male, 0 = female) will be included as a moderator (H5-H8).

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We will be powering our study to detect a small-medium effect of instructor presence (partial eta squared=.04; Wilson et al. 2018). A power analysis for the between subject condition (single evaluation) was conducted for a two tailed between subject t-test, with an effect size d=.4, and alpha=.05. With this criteria we will need 100 participants in each condition to reach .8 power. In total we will will collect 300 participants worth of data, 100 participants will complete the single evaluation with the instructor, and 100 without the instructor. The remain 100 will be in the joint evaluation condition to match the cell sizes.

analyses.value:
We will be conducting one within (joint evaluation) and one between (single evaluation) t-test looking at the effect of the instructor presence across each of our five dependent variables (comprehension, affect, mind wandering, overall liking, and JOL). We will also conduct a regression for comprehension using their score on a prior knowledge questions as a control. 

If the instructor presence effect is significant in the above analyses we will be conducting an Erlebacher's analysis (Erlebacher, 1977) to determine whether there is a significant interaction between design type (within subject vs. between subject). As Erlebacher's analysis requires equal cell sizes, participants may have to be excluded if we do not have an equal number of participants in each conditions. In these cases, those with the latest time stamps associated with their data will be removed.    

We will also be conducting correlations with all our dependent variables to see if there is a relation between comprehension and mind wandering and to explore if affect relates to comprehension or mind wandering. 

As noted above, in the single evaluation condition after the comprehension test participants will complete questions from the other lecture's comprehension tests. This will provide a no lecture baseline (i.e., expected performance when the associated lecture was not watched) for each set of comprehension questions. We will compare this no-lecture baseline to comprehension test performance in the group that watched the lecture using a t-test.

We will conduct an analysis that includes lecture (4 levels) as a factor to examine differences between lectures on our main dependent variables. This will consist of a 2 (instructor presence) x 4 (lecture) ANOVA focusing on the single evaluation condition only.

outliers.value: Failure to complete all aspects of the study (e.g., not watching the full video, not finishing the final test) will result in us excluding that participant's data.

dependent.value:
For participants in both the joint and single evaluation conditions: 
-Comprehension (test at the end of the lecture)  
-Affect (positive and negative affect scale: PANAS)
-Mind Wandering (with probes in the video) 
-A prior knowledge question (one of the test questions given before they watch the video lecture) 
-A rating of liking for the video overall
-Judgment of learning (JOL) before and after the test

For participants in the single evaluation condition:
-The comprehension test questions from the other video lectures they never watched

conditions.value: Participants will be assigned to watch either: 1) one video with an instructor, 2) one video without an instructor, or 3) two videos, one with an instructor and one without in counterbalanced order.

hypothesis.value:
We will be examining the instructor presence effect (i.e., the greater ratings of affect but lower comprehension scores for videos lectures with an instructor present compared to one without an instructor) across 2 evaluation conditions. In the single evaluation condition participants will only watch one video lecture, in the joint evaluation condition participants will watch two video lectures. 

We are interested in how the instructor's presence effects comprehension of the lecture material, mind wandering behaviours, and ratings of affect across a joint and single evaluation context.

q1.value: The Social Regulatory Functions of Emojis in Romantic Attachment Relationships

q2.value: Clayton Macgregor Jeffrey, Randy T. Lee, Vivian Zayas

q3.value: We are interested in examining how adult attachment style relates to the perceptions of emojis in text message exchanges sent between two romantic partners. In particular, we are looking to see how levels of attachment anxiety relate to how text exchanges using emojis (vs. not) are perceived in terms of relationship quality (e.g., commitment, satisfaction).

q4.value: We expect that dependent on the valence of the text exchange (positive or negative) the presence of emojis will amplify the perceived quality of the text exchange. It is hypothesized that positive messages will be perceived as having better relationship quality when emojis are used, and negative messages will be perceived as having worse relationship quality with the presence of emojis. We also expect that there will be an interaction with the level of anxiety in a participant’s adult attachment style and the perceived relationship quality of the text exchanges. We hypothesize that those with higher anxiety levels will further exaggerate the condition-specific effects when emojis are present.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Participants will be presented with text message exchange between two adult romantic partners. Each participant will read four sets of text exchanges, each exchange presumably from a different couple, and following each exchange, participants will make judgments about the relationship quality. The design is a mixed design with the valence of the text message exchange (positive vs. negative) a between subject factor, and the presence of emojis (yes vs. no) as a within subject factor.

q9.value: We will use block randomization with Qualtrics. Participants are randomized to one of two conditions, either positive valence text exchanges or negative valence text exchanges. Once assigned to one of these groups, participants are randomly presented with a message that either has an emoji or does not have an emoji. Participants will see a total of 4 exchanges, with an equal representation of emoji or no-emoji messages.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: This study was launched via Amazon MTurk on Feb. 20, 2020 and will be collecting data until the we have data for 400 participants. The data will not be downloaded for analysis until the survey has been ended on MTurk.

question.value: The data will be collected through registered Amazon MTurk workers. Participants must be registered with this online survey platform and must also be U.S. citizens. Data that indicates a failure to pass attention checks will be excluded from analysis. All participants who complete the 10-minute survey and pass the attention checks will be rewarded $1.21 (based on an MTurk average wage of $7.25 per hour). The survey will be available until Feb. 27, 2020, or until 400 participants have completed the survey.

q13.value: 400 participants will be recruited to ensure that this study has adequate statistical power. All participants must be 18 years of age or older, must be citizens in the U.S. and must be registered Amazon MTurk workers.

q14.value: Based on a G*Power analysis, the minimum number of participants required to have detect 0.2 correlation with 95% statistical power in a two-tailed test is 314 participants. To account for outliers and other omitted data, this study will aim at recruiting 400 participants to ensure that these statistical parameters are met.

question.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to either a positive valence condition or a negative valence condition. All participants will also be presented with text exchanges that either include the presence of emojis or do not include emojis. Each participant will be presented with two text exchanges that include emojis and two text exchanges that do not include emojis.

After seeing a text exchange, participants will rate on a scale from 1-7 the extent to which they agree with the following DVs: These partners are likely to end their relationship in the near future, This exchange was positive, These partners are very attached to their relationship – very strongly linked to each other, These partners will date someone other than each other, This exchange was hostile, These partners feel satisfied with their relationship, Their relationship is much better than others’ relationships, They love each other, This exchange was serious.

We will perform a reliability analysis. Assuming acceptable levels (greater than .7), we will compute an aggregate reflecting the overall quality of the perceived relationship. We will also look at the individual sub-scales of perceived commitment, satisfaction and tone.

We will conduct a two-way mixed ANOVA with valence as a between factors and emoji as a within factor. We will also perform multiple regression. Specifically, for each valence, we will compute   the effect of emoji use by computing the difference between evaluations for messages with emojis minus evaluations for messages without emojis. This will be our primary dependent variable. We will enter as predictors, adult attachment anxiety, attachment avoidance, as well as the interaction between the two. To see if the effect of attachment and perceptions of relationship quality as a function of emoji use depend on the valence of the message, we will compare the regression coefficients for attachment anxiety between the two models.

q20.value: To compute regression tests, the mean scores of attachment anxiety and attachment avoidance will need to be mean centred. To do this, scores of anxiety and avoidance will be transformed into variables that have subtracted the mean attachment anxiety/avoidance from each value.

q21.value: We will use the standard p< 0.05 criteria to determine if the results from two-way ANOVA and the follow-up tests suggest that the results are significantly different from the null hypothesis. We will be using two-tailed for our analysis.

q22.value: We will exclude data for participants who did not pass attention checks throughout the duration of the survey. Additionally, outliers (3 standard deviations above or below the mean) will be examined and omitted.

q23.value: If a participant completes less than 7 of the 9 evaluations of the relationship for a text exchange then their data will be excluded. On the ECR, a 36-item questionnaire which measures attachment, if a participant fails to complete at least 30 items their data will be excluded from the analysis.
